questions.question_text: A technician is configuring a wireless access point in a public space for guests to use. Which of the following should the technician configure so that only approved connections are allowed?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Public setting, guests ---> captive portal

Selected Answer: B
nslookup (name server lookup) is a tool used to perform DNS lookups in Linux. It is used to display DNS details, such as the IP address of a particular computer, the MX records for a domain, or the NS servers of a domain

comments.content: In certmaster lear is states "In a Windows environment, you can troubleshoot DNS name resolution with the nslookup command" Since the question is asking about Linux, I would assume the answer is "dig"

Just occurred to me that they're specifying that the technician needs to "confirm the server names for all Linux servers" - tricky phrasing from the question, but it implies that the servers are running Linux, not necessarily that the technician is, so nslookup would be viable for this question
The question states "The technician needs to confirm the server name for all Linux servers" it doesn't state anything about him remoting on another OS. So I agree the answer should be "dig"

When using the CLI on those OSs, yes. However, the technician in question isn't necessarily running those commands on Linux; all we definitively know is that he's trying to verify the hostnames, which he can do remotely on another OS.

discussion.content: I thought you had to use "dig" for macOS and Linux devices.

To confirm the server name for Linux servers, the technician should run the following command:

B. nslookup

The "nslookup" command is used to query DNS (Domain Name System) servers to obtain information about domain names, including resolving domain names to IP addresses and vice versa. By running "nslookup" with the server's IP address, the technician can retrieve the corresponding hostname (server name) associated with that IP address from the DNS records. This command helps identify the server names in a Linux server farm setup.
where is the "dig" option ??????????????
DIG,NSLOOKUP, AND HOSTNAME are the possible answers.

Selected Answer: B
The NSLOOKUP command does what the question is asking - searching for the name of the device/server.

Selected Answer: B
This tripped me up because to me a computer name is its hostname not its FQDN name as you would get when you use nslookup against a machine. CompTIA...

Selected Answer: B
Nslookup (stands for “Name Server Lookup”) is a useful command for getting information from the DNS server. It is a network administration tool for querying the Domain Name System (DNS) to obtain domain name or IP address mapping or any other specific DNS record. It is also used to troubleshoot DNS-related problems.

Selected Answer: C
Address Resolution Translation resolves IP address to name.

comments.content:
DNS (Domain Name Service) resolves IP address to name.
ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) resolves physical (MAC) address to IP address.
Address Resolution Translation is not a thing.

DNS do that, not ARP
The Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) - associates the 2 numeric addresses in the network => Mac + IP
Of course, this is not the right answer!
what does that have to do with anything?

ARP resolve mac address to IP address.
RARP does the reverse.

questions.question_text: A technician is writing documentation regarding a company's server farm. The technician needs to confirm the server name for all Linux servers. Which of the following commands should the technician run?

A network technician added a new workstation to the network and needs to make a custom, shielded cable that is 492ft (150m) with both ends wired to TIA/EIA-568A standards. The workstation is not establishing a link to the switchport. Which of the following is the cause of the issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Distance Limitations Of Shielded Twisted Pair
The max distance for STP ethernet cables is 100m (330ft), although some categories only offer peak performance up to 55m (180ft).

comments.content: if Auto MDI-X is not supported or disabled on either the workstation or the switch, you should use a straight-through cable to connect them.

discussion.content:
C. Incorrect pinout.

This is because if the cable was made with both ends wired to TIA/EIA-568A standards, then the pinout configuration should match on both ends. If one end is wired to TIA/EIA-568A standards and the other end is wired to TIA/EIA-568B standards, or if there are errors in the wiring order of the cable, it can lead to connectivity issues and prevent the workstation from establishing a link to the switchport.

The other options, such as cable shielding (option A), attenuation (option B), and near-end crosstalk (option D), could potentially cause issues with the connection quality, but they are less likely to be the primary cause of the workstation's inability to establish a link compared to an incorrect pinout.

Selected Answer: B
It's B the cable went past its limit of 100 meters.
I go with C

B. is the answer
From ChatGPT-
Ethernet Category 5e (Cat 5e): Cat 5e cables also have a maximum length of about 100 meters (328 feet), but they offer better performance and are more suitable for Gigabit Ethernet compared to Cat 5 cables.

C. Incorrect pinout

Explanation:
In the TIA/EIA-568A standard, both ends of the cable should be wired in the same pinout configuration. If the pinout is incorrect on one end of the cable, it will result in a mismatch between the wiring of the workstation's Ethernet interface and the wiring of the switchport, preventing the establishment of a link.

Selected Answer: B
B.

You would tracert (which gives you the hops) to understand the issue. If the remote site suddenly has 10 more hops, then the ISP is improperly routing their traffic.

Selected Answer: B
Wouldn't NetFlow data have B. Hop by hop network latency metrics? The question is asking for a metric.

Selected Answer: B
GPTTTT

Selected Answer: D
The answer is D. Server NetFlow data, when you ask ChatGPT it states that "Server NetFlow data provides insights into the traffic patterns and volume going to and from the server. By analyzing this data, the network administrator can identify any anomalies or bottlenecks that may be causing the slowdown specifically for users in the remote office. This could include factors such as high traffic volume, network congestion, or packet loss."

comments.content:
ChatGPT gave me B as the answer:
The best metric for a network administrator to check in this situation is:

**B. Hop-by-hop network latency**

This is because the issue is related to the remote office users experiencing slower page load times compared to those in the main corporate office. Hop-by-hop network latency will help identify any delays occurring at each hop along the network path from the remote office to the corporate web server. This can help pinpoint where the latency is being introduced, whether it's within the corporate network or on the wider internet. Identifying high latency at specific hops can lead to finding and resolving the underlying issue affecting the remote office users.

questions.question_text: Users in a remote office report that corporate web server pages are taking a long time to load, whereas users in the main corporate office do not have any issues. Which of the following is the best metric for a network administrator to check?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Going with D, VPN concentrator is typically situated next too, or just behind the FW. According to CBT Nugs

Selected Answer: D
A VPN headend is typically located at the Wide Area Network (WAN) edge

Selected Answer: D
A VPN concentrator is typically placed at the edge of the network, behind the firewall, and before the router, to securely manage VPN traffic for remote users and site-to-site connections.

comments.content:
Nevermind, after further research it's apparent that VPN concentrators are placed in the core. 

https://documentation.meraki.com/MX/Deployment_Guides/VPN_Concentrator_Deployment_Guide

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
A VPN becomes the default gateway of the entire network, therefore I'm going to say WAN edge.

Selected Answer: C
A VPN headend is typically located in the core layer of a network. This is where the central processing for VPN connections occurs, handling incoming VPN traffic from various sites or remote users.

Distribution: Middle-tier, routing between access and core layers.
Access: End-user connectivity to the network.
Core: High-speed, central part of the network.
WAN edge: Interface between an enterprise network and external networks.

questions.question_text: In which of the following locations is a VPN headend found?
